entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Insert CJK inter-script spacing: the CSS `text-autospace` property
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Insert CJK inter-script spacing: the CSS `text-autospace` property
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Insert+CJK+inter%5C-script+spacing%5C%3A+the+CSS+%60text%5C-autospace%60+property%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Insert CJK inter-script spacing: the CSS `text-autospace` property</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250702" rel="nofollow">Wed, 02 Jul 2025 08:19:34 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM1
/Daniel</pre><pre>
On 2025-06-17 04:35, Domenic Denicola wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>Thanks for these updates. Do you have any ideas on when the WebKit </tt><tt>difference might be resolved? We shouldn't block shipping on them, but </tt><tt>if there's a chance that the initial value might change due to ongoing </tt><tt>discussions, it would be good to know that before we ship. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On Fri, Jun 13, 2025 at 3:43 PM Koji Ishii <ko...@chromium.org> wrote:
Thank you for the detailed reply.
2025年6月13日(金) 10:33 Domenic Denicola <dome...@chromium.org>:
Summary
Inserts small spacings to match the established typographic rules automatically. The spec currently defines one rule for Han ideographic characters and one for French. The initial implementation focuses on the Han ideographic characters rule. Text written in Han ideographic writing systems often mixes multiple scripts, usually the Han ideographic scripts, Latin scripts, and ASCII digits. Small spacings when switching from and to non-Han ideographic scripts often help readability. This property lets browsers insert such spacings automatically. This property has several values, including values for other writing systems. The initial implementation supports the following subset: `text-autospace: normal | no-autospace`. This feature also includes the `text-spacing` shorthand, as now all longhands are available.
Not blocking, but I am curious if we have an objection to the other 6 values? Or are they just lower priority?
No objections, just lower priority. Many apps/platforms implemented this feature, Blink's initial support is at the same level as iOS. MS Word provides alpha/numeric distinctions. As far as I know, InDesign is the only app that provides `punctuation`, and no apps provide `insert` and `replace`.
/WebKit/: Shipped/Shipping
(<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.apple.com/documentation/safari-release-notes/safari-18_4-release-notes#CSS">https://developer.apple.com/documentation/safari-release-notes/safari-18_4-release-notes#CSS</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.apple.com/documentation/safari-release-notes/safari-18_4-release-notes#CSS">https://developer.apple.com/documentation/safari-release-notes/safari-18_4-release-notes#CSS</a>>)
It seems like we will not be interoperable with Safari by shipping this, because of the different initial value. So, I think opening a standards position request would be valuable. If they do not intend to align their initial value with the spec, e.g. for performance reasons, then that would be good for us to know.
They have filed a bug by themselves <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=287355">https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=287355</a>>, and we're discussing it offline. I shared our experiences on the performance with them and they're looking into it.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?Yes
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-text?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=text-autospace">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-text?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=text-autospace</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-text?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=text-autospace">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-text?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=text-autospace</a>>
Safari fails many of these tests. Is that only due to the initial value difference? Or are the mismatches here revealing other interoperability issues?
For parsing tests, they also shipped a subset, so they're fine.
For rendering, 2 out of 4 failures are due to the initial value difference. One real failure is an RTL test which I think is not likely a real use case. Another is a Chinese test for a recent spec change.
Also, you state that shipping this feature will include shipping the text-spacing shorthand. Are there tests available for that property?
Thanks, good catch, I missed it. Since this is a shorthand, there're only parsing tests (added to the chromestatus page too)
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-text/parsing?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=text-spacing%20and%20not%28text-spacing-trim%29">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-text/parsing?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=text-spacing%20and%20not%28text-spacing-trim%29</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-text/parsing?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=text-spacing%20and%20not%28text-spacing-trim%29">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-text/parsing?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=text-spacing%20and%20not%28text-spacing-trim%29</a>> One failure in Blink is due to not shipping the `auto <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-text-4/#valdef-text-autospace-auto">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-text-4/#valdef-text-autospace-auto</a>>` value. This is a platform-specific value, but we can't simulate what iOS does.
Flag name on about://flags
Finch feature name
Non-finch justificationNone
A Finch feature name is required for new features.
Thank you for pointing this out, fixed.
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/11013">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/11013</a> seems relevant, and resolved. Do you know if there is any blocker for incorporating the edits into the specification?
Blink implements this resolution. The spec update is just due to not anyone taking it, I'll work on it.
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/9857">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/9857</a> also seems a bit worrying, about the stability of the text-spacing part of this intent.
As noted above, `auto` is the value for platform-specific behavior, so that browsers can ship the OS-compatible behavior, similar to `font-family: system-ui <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-family#system-ui">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-family#system-ui</a>>`. Blink doesn't ship this value, so that authors can at least know the behavior isn't available.
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/9471">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/9471</a> also seems potentially like an issue that might affect this, but I cannot tell for certain.
Sorry this is left over. There were many discussions on each character like this. This led us to think that we need a standard at the Unicode-level, and hence the UTR#59 <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://unicode.org/reports/tr59/">https://unicode.org/reports/tr59/</a>> was born. I commented and closed.
-- </pre><tt>You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google </tt><tt>Groups "blink-dev" group. </tt><tt>To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send </tt><tt>an email to blink-dev+unsubscr...@chromium.org. </tt><tt>To view this discussion visit </tt><tt><a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAM0wra-o-GDWgjPbXHH0J6MAA-%2BLb6c9Hp40Wt9%2BknVFei9w4Q%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAM0wra-o-GDWgjPbXHH0J6MAA-%2BLb6c9Hp40Wt9%2BknVFei9w4Q%40mail.gmail.com</a> </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAM0wra-o-GDWgjPbXHH0J6MAA-%2BLb6c9Hp40Wt9%2BknVFei9w4Q%40mail.gmail.com?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAM0wra-o-GDWgjPbXHH0J6MAA-%2BLb6c9Hp40Wt9%2BknVFei9w4Q%40mail.gmail.com?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer</a>>. </tt></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;">

entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+%5C%5BEXTERNAL%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Support+font%5C-feature%5C-settings+descriptor+in+%40font%5C-face+rule%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: Intent to Ship: Support font-feature-settings descriptor in @font-face rule</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27Sejal+Anand%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'Sejal Anand' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250702" rel="nofollow">Wed, 02 Jul 2025 21:50:39 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>
Hi Philip, Daniel,</pre><pre>
I have initiated the API owner review along with other reviews, which should now be visible. A separate email has been sent for the review. Please take a moment to look over it. Thank you for your time.
Thank you, Sejal
________________________________ From: Philip Jägenstedt <foo...@chromium.org> Sent: Wednesday, July 2, 2025 9:08 PM To: Daniel Bratell <bratel...@gmail.com> Cc: Sejal Anand <sejalan...@microsoft.com>; 一丝 <yio...@gmail.com>; blink-dev <blink-dev@chromium.org>; Ragvesh Sharma's Organization (FTE) <ragvesh_org_...@microsoft.com> Subject: Re: [blink-dev] Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: Intent to Ship: Support font-feature-settings descriptor in @font-face rule
Hi Sejal,
It's great to the progress on this, I believe it's one of the most highly upvoted font-related features.
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5102801981800448">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5102801981800448</a> still doesn't show up in the list of features to review/approve, please feel free to reach out off list if you can't find the right buttons to press.
Best regards, Philip
On Wed, Jul 2, 2025 at 4:51 PM Daniel Bratell <bratel...@gmail.com<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:bratel...@gmail.com">mailto:bratel...@gmail.com</a>>> wrote:
This does not show up on the API Owner dashboard in Chromestatus so maybe you have missed pushing it there? There are some other reviews that should be started there at the same time.
/Daniel
On 2025-07-02 07:04, 'Sejal Anand' via blink-dev wrote:
The review for the font-variation-settings CL<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6582382">https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6582382</a>> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6582382">https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6582382</a>> is currently underway. Due to notable differences in implementation and interoperability, I have created a separate Chrome status entry for it. If necessary, we can wait until the variation settings CL is merged.
Thank you, Sejal
________________________________ From: 一丝 <yio...@gmail.com><<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:yio...@gmail.com">mailto:yio...@gmail.com</a>> Sent: Monday, June 30, 2025 2:22 PM To: blink-dev <blink-dev@chromium.org><<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:blink-dev@chromium.org">mailto:blink-dev@chromium.org</a>> Cc: Sejal Anand <sejalan...@microsoft.com><<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:sejalan...@microsoft.com">mailto:sejalan...@microsoft.com</a>>; Ragvesh Sharma's Organization (FTE) <ragvesh_org_...@microsoft.com><<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:ragvesh_org_...@microsoft.com">mailto:ragvesh_org_...@microsoft.com</a>> Subject: [EXTERNAL] Re: Intent to Ship: Support font-feature-settings descriptor in @font-face rule
You don't often get email from yio...@gmail.com<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:yio...@gmail.com">mailto:yio...@gmail.com</a>>. Learn why this is important<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification">https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification</a>>
Thanks for your work, this is a feature that Blink has been lacking for a long time, very much looking forward to it!
Are you planning to ship the `font-variation-settings` together? We hope they can be released together.
在2025年6月29日星期日 UTC+8 15:57:03<sejal...@microsoft.com><<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:sejal...@microsoft.com">mailto:sejal...@microsoft.com</a>> 写道：
Contact emails sejal...@microsoft.com
Explainer None
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-fonts-4/#font-rend-desc">https://www.w3.org/TR/css-fonts-4/#font-rend-desc</a>
Summary As CSS allows fine control over font features using 'font-feature-settings' at the element level, Chromium-based browsers currently lack support for these properties within '@font-face' declarations.
This feature supports the string-based syntax for font-feature-settings as defined in CSS Fonts Level 4. Invalid or unrecognized feature tags will be ignored per specification. No binary or non-standard forms are supported.
As OpenType fonts become more widely adopted, this enhancement will improve typographic control, reduce redundancy, and support a more scalable, modern approach to web design.
Blink component Blink>Fonts<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EFonts%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EFonts%22</a>>
Motivation CSS already provides a 'font-feature-settings' property for controlling OpenType features at the element level. However, Chromium does not currently support it within @font-face declarations, unlike Firefox and Safari.
This limitation prevents developers from configuring font behavior during font loading, forcing redundant declarations across individual components or elements.
Supporting these descriptors in Chromium would let developers define font behavior once—at the source—improving consistency, reducing repetition, and making it easier to verify applied settings through DevTools.
Initial public proposal None
TAG review None
TAG review status Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
Gecko: Shipped/Shipping (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1355366">https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1355366</a>)
WebKit: Shipped/Shipping (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=63618">https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=63618</a>)
Web developers: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27486680/how-to-set-default-font-feature-settings">https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27486680/how-to-set-default-font-feature-settings</a>) Over 30 users have indicated that they are affected by this issue and its related duplicates, as noted in <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40398871">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40398871</a> and <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/324519293">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/324519293</a>
Other signals:
WebView application risks Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications? None
Debuggability Existing DevTools capabilities already cover this.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>? Yes <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-fonts/font-feature-settings-descriptor-02.html?label=master&label=experimental&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-fonts/font-feature-settings-descriptor-02.html?label=master&label=experimental&aligned</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-fonts?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=font-feature-settings-descriptor-binary.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-fonts?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=font-feature-settings-descriptor-binary.html</a>
Flag name on about://flags
Finch feature name FontFeatureSettingsDescriptor
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40398871">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40398871</a>
Estimated milestones Shipping on desktop 139 Shipping on Android 139 Shipping on WebView 139 Shipping on iOS 139
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5102801981800448?gate=5099341546782720">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5102801981800448?gate=5099341546782720</a>

entry.summary: Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Support font-feature-settings descriptor in @font-face rule
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5BEXTERNAL%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Support+font%5C-feature%5C-settings+descriptor+in+%40font%5C-face+rule%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Support font-feature-settings descriptor in @font-face rule</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27Sejal+Anand%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'Sejal Anand' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250706" rel="nofollow">Sun, 06 Jul 2025 22:51:43 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>
Thank you Philip for your approval, font-variation-settings CL is also merged, I'll ship both of them together.</pre><pre>
________________________________ From: Philip Jägenstedt <foo...@chromium.org> Sent: Saturday, July 5, 2025 1:54 PM To: Chromestatus <ad...@cr-status.appspotmail.com> Cc: blink-dev@chromium.org <blink-dev@chromium.org>; Ragvesh Sharma's Organization (FTE) <ragvesh_org_...@microsoft.com> Subject: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Support font-feature-settings descriptor in @font-face rule
LGTM1, thank you for addressing this pain point for developers!
The scope of this intent is font-feature-settings, but now that <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6582382">https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6582382</a> has been merged, do you want to ship support for font-feature-settings and font-variation-settings together? I think that would be great, but my LGTM is not conditional on it.
I also confirmed that the linked tests are failing on stable but passing on experimental, so everything seems to be in good order!
On Thu, Jul 3, 2025 at 4:53 AM Chromestatus <ad...@cr-status.appspotmail.com<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:ad...@cr-status.appspotmail.com">mailto:ad...@cr-status.appspotmail.com</a>>> wrote: Contact emails sejalan...@microsoft.com<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:sejalan...@microsoft.com">mailto:sejalan...@microsoft.com</a>>
Explainer None
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-fonts-4/#font-rend-desc">https://www.w3.org/TR/css-fonts-4/#font-rend-desc</a>
Summary
As CSS allows fine control over font features using 'font-feature-settings' at the element level, Chromium-based browsers currently lack support for these properties within '@font-face' declarations. This feature supports the string-based syntax for font-feature-settings as defined in CSS Fonts Level 4. Invalid or unrecognized feature tags will be ignored per specification. No binary or non-standard forms are supported. As OpenType fonts become more widely adopted, this enhancement will improve typographic control, reduce redundancy, and support a more scalable, modern approach to web design.
Blink component Blink>Fonts<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EFonts%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EFonts%22</a>>
TAG review None
TAG review status Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
Gecko: Shipped/Shipping (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1355366">https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1355366</a>)
WebKit: Shipped/Shipping (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=63618">https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=63618</a>)
Web developers: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27486680/how-to-set-default-font-feature-settings">https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27486680/how-to-set-default-font-feature-settings</a>) Over 30 users have indicated that they are affected by this issue and its related duplicates, as noted in <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40398871">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40398871</a> and <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/324519293">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/324519293</a>
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Debuggability
Existing DevTools capabilities already cover this.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>? Yes
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-fonts/font-feature-settings-descriptor-02.html?label=master&label=experimental&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-fonts/font-feature-settings-descriptor-02.html?label=master&label=experimental&aligned</a>

Flag name on about://flags

Rollout plan Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40398871">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40398871</a>
Estimated milestones Shipping on desktop 139 Shipping on Android 139 Shipping on WebView 139 Shipping on iOS 139
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).
None

<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Experiment%5C%3A+Per%5C-Function+Explicit+Compile+Hints+via+Magic+Comments%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Per-Function Explicit Compile Hints via Magic Comments</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250707" rel="nofollow">Mon, 07 Jul 2025 08:03:11 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> Nope - no concerns from me.
On 7/3/25 3:11 a.m., Marja Hölttä wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>Thanks for looking into it! Unfortunately we don't have a range of </tt><tt>milestones now, so I'll need to come back to this thread when we have. </tt><tt>By sending this request early we were hoping that if there are any </tt><tt>concerns or action items to do before getting the approval, we'd get </tt><tt>to know about them early, and when our partner is ready we'd be also </tt><tt>ready to start the experiment. Please let me know if there are any </tt><tt>such concerns or action items currently known. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre></pre><tt>(I added a comment to the requests-for-position about the per-function </tt><tt>extension of this proposal.) </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On Thu, Jun 5, 2025 at 2:36 PM Mike Taylor <miketa...@chromium.org> wrote:
On 6/5/25 8:17 AM, 'Marja Hölttä' via blink-dev wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Contact emails ma...@google.com
Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/explicit-javascript-compile-hints-file-based">https://github.com/WICG/explicit-javascript-compile-hints-file-based</a>
Specification There's no spec or draft spec for the per-function part yet - getting feedback on the input format is one of the goals of the Origin Trial.
Summary Allow attaching information about which functions should be eager parsed & compiled in JavaScript files.
The information will be encoded as magic comments.
This is an extension of the Per-File Explicit Compile Hints feature ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5100466238652416">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5100466238652416</a> ), where we now allow marking individual functions for eager parsing & compilation.
Blink component Blink>JavaScript
TAG review None
TAG review status Pending
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility None
Gecko: N/A (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/780">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/780</a>) This is a position request for the previous iteration of compile hints; the per-file version. We expect their views about this extension to be similar.
WebKit: N/A (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/172">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/172</a>) This is a position request for the previous iteration of compile hints; the per-file version. We expect their views about this extension to be similar. </pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Non-blocking feedback: adding a comment about this proposal to those existing issues seems good. </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Web developers: Positive - Microsoft is interested in prototyping; needs the Origin Trial for evaluating performance in the wild - General positive sentiment, e.g., TC39 tooling meeting
Other signals:
WebView application risks Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Goals for experimentation
- Evaluate the performance improvement potential for real world web apps - Get feedback about the input format
Ongoing technical constraints None
Debuggability None
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? No
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? No
Flag name on about://flags None
Finch feature name None
Non-finch justification Web developers need to enable this feature on their side; adding a Finch flag as an additional gate doesn't make sense.
Requires code in //chrome? False
Estimated milestones No milestones specified (Will need to wait for partners to be ready to start the Origin Trial) </pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;">
We will need a range of milestones before approving. One of two options might work for you:
1) You request 6 milestones now starting in MXXX (i.e., M140 to M145), if you're reasonably confident your partners can be experiment in that window.
2) You come back to the thread once you know which milestones you are requesting and we can approve then.
</pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">

entry.title: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: highlightsFromPoint API
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: highlightsFromPoint API
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+highlightsFromPoint+API%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: highlightsFromPoint API</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27Fernando+Fiori%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'Fernando Fiori' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250708" rel="nofollow">Tue, 08 Jul 2025 11:19:14 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Hi,
I'm reactivating this thread after some updates addressing feedback received here:
- highlightsFromPoint now also returns the ranges hit for each Highlight under a given point after discussing it with the CSSWG <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/12031">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/12031</a>> (cc @Stephen) to make the API more useful for many real-life scenarios. There are more details in the explainer <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/ffiori/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/master/highlight/HighlightsFromPointsExplainer.md">https://github.com/ffiori/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/master/highlight/HighlightsFromPointsExplainer.md</a>> and specs <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-highlight-api-1/#interactions">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-highlight-api-1/#interactions</a>>, basically the type has been changed to the following:</pre><pre>
sequence<HighlightHitResult> highlightsFromPoint(float x, float y, optional HighlightsFromPointOptions options = {});
dictionary HighlightHitResult { Highlight highlight; sequence<AbstractRange> ranges; };
- The explainer <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/ffiori/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/master/highlight/HighlightsFromPointsExplainer.md">https://github.com/ffiori/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/master/highlight/HighlightsFromPointsExplainer.md</a>> was updated to match the new type mentioned above, expanded the Alternative Solutions section with further variations, and expanded on how the API addresses customer needs (as suggested by @Alex).
- Regarding the concerns about the API being synchronous, other async options were explored more in detail (see Alternative Solutions section <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/ffiori/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/master/highlight/HighlightsFromPointsExplainer.md#alternative-solutions">https://github.com/ffiori/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/master/highlight/HighlightsFromPointsExplainer.md#alternative-solutions</a>> in the explainer) but we decided to continue pursuing the synchronous format. It's simpler and more developer-friendly, and matches the syntax and style of other existing *FromPoint APIs. Additionally, we believe that the question of synchronous-layout-requiring APIs is better addressed separately so that all of these similar *FromPoint APIs can be considered holistically (Alex's proposal on Event Phases <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/MicrosoftEdge/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/main/EventPhases/explainer.md">https://github.com/MicrosoftEdge/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/main/EventPhases/explainer.md</a>> is a great example of how this can be approached).
By the way, I also updated the shipping Estimated Milestones to 140.
Looking forward to any feedback you might have :)
Thanks, Fernando
El lunes, 3 de marzo de 2025 a la(s) 12:16:09 p.m. UTC-8, Fernando Fiori escribió:
@Domenic, thanks for your feedback, I just updated the milestones. Regards the CSSWG current status on the feature, there's been consensus on it prior to its I2P and implementations, you can refer to this comment (and all the discussion taking place in that issue): [css-highlight-api] Approaches for dispatching highlight pointer events · Issue #7513 · w3c/csswg-drafts <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7513#issuecomment-1248320696">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7513#issuecomment-1248320696</a>>.
@Stephen, thanks a lot, that'd be amazing :)
@Robert, I see, thanks for clarifying! I thought you meant replacing highlightsFromPoint to also return Elements with the additional parameters you mentioned in your last message, my comment was related to most of the use cases discussed can be satisfied with the simpler highlightsFromPoint API described in this I2S and the specs linked. I could see both APIs coexisting in the future, but I'm still not super clear on what use cases the API you describe could be applied to, I think your proposal could definitely be further discussed in an issue in the CSSWG for a broader audience.
As per @Alex's comments, I'm working on updating the explainer to capture all the details about alternative solutions and why this one was chosen over them there so it's clearer and more centralized.
I'll let you know when the explainer updates are done.
Thank you all for the feedback, Fernando
El domingo, 2 de marzo de 2025 a la(s) 6:43:21 p.m. UTC-8, Domenic Denicola escribió:
This states "shipping on desktop" but also "supported on all six Blink platforms". Perhaps you just forgot to add the milestones for Android and Android WebView?
It seems there's some late-breaking feedback from both Google and Microsoft engineers in this thread on the API design. I'm unclear to what extent those engineers have raised their concerns to the CSSWG. Can you give us a sense of the CSSWG's current consensus status on this feature? This looks ready to ship to me, but this amount of discussion muddles the situation a bit.
On Saturday, February 15, 2025 at 9:59:59 AM UTC+9 Fernando Fiori wrote:
*Contact emails*
stephan...@microsoft.com, sa...@microsoft.com, ffi...@microsoft.com
*Explainer*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/MicrosoftEdge/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/main/highlight/HighlightsFromPointsExplainer.md">https://github.com/MicrosoftEdge/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/main/highlight/HighlightsFromPointsExplainer.md</a>
*Specification*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-highlight-api-1/#interactions">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-highlight-api-1/#interactions</a>
*Summary*
The highlightsFromPoint API enables developers to interact with custom highlights by detecting which highlights exist at a specific point within a document. This interactivity is valuable for complex web features where multiple highlights may overlap or exist within shadow DOM. By providing precise point-based highlight detection, the API empowers developers to manage dynamic interactions with custom highlights more effectively, such as responding to user clicks or hover events on highlighted regions to trigger custom tooltips, context menus, or other interactive features.
*Blink component*
Blink>CSS <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22</a>>
*TAG review*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1043">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1043</a>
*TAG review status*
Issues addressed
*Risks*
*Interoperability and Compatibility*
The 'highlightsFromPoint' API is a new feature so there isn’t a compatibility risk. The interoperability risk is limited to the usual risk of limited adoption and/or inconsistent browser support for a new feature.
*Gecko*: No signal ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1068">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1068</a>)
*WebKit*: No signal ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/394">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/394</a>)
*Web developers*: Positive ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7513#issuecomment-1211033472">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7513#issuecomment-1211033472</a>, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7447#issuecomment-2386160133">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7447#issuecomment-2386160133</a>, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7447#issuecomment-1183422904">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7447#issuecomment-1183422904</a>)

None

None

None

None

Yes

Yes
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-highlight-api/HighlightRegistry-highlightsFromPoint.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-highlight-api/HighlightRegistry-highlightsFromPoint.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>

Note that these tests are currently failing in wpt.fyi because the feature still has the status test in code <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/runtime_enabled_features.json5;l=2333?q=runtime_enabled_features.json&ss=chromium%2Fchromium%2Fsrc">https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/runtime_enabled_features.json5;l=2333?q=runtime_enabled_features.json&ss=chromium%2Fchromium%2Fsrc</a>>,

The scope of this intent is font-feature-settings, but now that <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6582382">https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6582382</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6582382">https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6582382</a>> has been merged, do you want to ship support for font-feature-settings and font-variation-settings together? I think that would be great, but my LGTM is not conditional on it.
I also confirmed that the linked tests are failing on stable but passing on experimental, so everything seems to be in good order!

Summary
As CSS allows fine control over font features using 'font-feature-settings' at the element level, Chromium-based browsers currently lack support for these properties within '@font-face' declarations. This feature supports the string-based syntax for font-feature-settings as defined in CSS Fonts Level 4. Invalid or unrecognized feature tags will be ignored per specification. No binary or non-standard forms are supported. As OpenType fonts become more widely adopted, this enhancement will improve typographic control, reduce redundancy, and support a more scalable, modern approach to web design.

<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Prototype%5C%3A+Script+Tools+API%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: Script Tools API</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22David+Bokan%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">David Bokan</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250709" rel="nofollow">Wed, 09 Jul 2025 09:36:29 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emailsbo...@chromium.org, hvanops...@chromium.org, khushalsa...@chromium.org</pre><pre>
ExplainerNone - We're working to publish an explainer ASAP and will link it on this thread when it's available.
SpecificationNone
Summary
Script Tools enable authors to expose JavaScript APIs on their site for automated use by the user agent. They allow an author to annotate these APIs with descriptions and provide input schema, allowing automation frameworks a more specific method to access the site's functionality.
Blink componentBlink <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%22</a>>
Motivation
Automation over web pages is an increasingly active area. Currently, web APIs provide no direct way to interact with automation frameworks so these frameworks rely on simulating user input on pages. Script Tools aims to provide a way for participating web sites to provide automation-specific paths in their UI. Automation can then proceed more quickly and enables the web site's UI to react.

Summary
The shape of the caret in native applications is most commonly a vertical bar, an underscore or a rectangular block. In addition, the shape often varies depending on the input mode, such as insert or replace. The CSS caret-shape property allows sites to choose one of these shapes for the caret inside editable elements, or leave the choice up to the browser. Specification None
Summary
Enables web documents to detect and report resources with unoptimized network usage, to minimize their performance impact. By identifying and flagging resource usage behaviors that can degrade performance, developers gain greater control over the user experience, enabling them to address issues for smoother interactions and improved responsiveness across web documents and applications.
Blink component Blink <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%22</a>>
Motivation
The user experience of a web document can be impacted by the performance of its embedded resources and iframes. There is currently no mechanism to prevent these resources (and frames in particular) from engaging in behavior that degrades performance, or to flag this behavior, leaving embedding documents with little control over the experience of their users.
Initial public proposal <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/proposals/issues/202">https://github.com/WICG/proposals/issues/202</a>

entry.summary: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: CSS find-in-page highlight pseudos
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+CSS+find%5C-in%5C-page+highlight+pseudos%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: CSS find-in-page highlight pseudos</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Domenic+Denicola%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Domenic Denicola</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250713" rel="nofollow">Sun, 13 Jul 2025 20:58:40 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>
On Thursday, July 10, 2025 at 4:41:12 AM UTC+9 Chromestatus wrote:</pre><pre>
Contact emails schen...@chromium.org, ji...@igalia.com
Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/Igalia/explainers/blob/main/css/find-">https://github.com/Igalia/explainers/blob/main/css/find-</a> in-page/README.md
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-pseudo-4/#selectordef-search-text">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-pseudo-4/#selectordef-search-text</a>
Design docs <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/Igalia/explainers/blob/main/css/find-in-page/README.md">https://github.com/Igalia/explainers/blob/main/css/find-in-page/README.md</a>
Summary
Exposes find-in-page search result styling to authors as a highlight pseudo-element, like selection and spelling errors. This allows authors to change the foreground and background colors or add text decorations, which can be especially useful if the UA defaults have insufficient contrast with the page colors or are otherwise unsuitable.
Blink component Blink>CSS <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22</a>>
Search tags search <<a rel="nofollow" href="http:///features#tags:search">http:///features#tags:search</a>>
TAG review None
TAG review status Not applicable
Can you explain why it is not applicable? I can't see which exception <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.chromium.org/blink/launching-features/wide-review/#exceptions">https://www.chromium.org/blink/launching-features/wide-review/#exceptions</a>> category it might fall into.
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
The feature is in the CSS Pseudo spec and there are no open issues. The behavior is designed to be implementable in Firefox and Chrome, but is unlikely to be viable in Safari due to highly customize UI for find-in-page. The spec is explicit that browsers may choose not to implement this feature provided @supports information is correct. The Safari behavior is so different that developers are unlikely to believe their styling would apply there.
*Gecko*: Under consideration (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/">https://github.com/mozilla/</a> standards-positions/issues/1103)
*WebKit*: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/">https://github.com/WebKit/</a> standards-positions/issues/421) Will file a request for position, but in spec conversations were neutral with no expectation of implementing it themselves.
*Web developers*: Positive Developers wishing to avoid conflicts with the find-in-page colors and their page styles have requested this feature. Someone directly asks for CSS styling of find-in-page:https:// stackoverflow.com/questions/50309703/css-for-browsers-find-in-page Another direct question: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/18666075/how-to-">https://stackoverflow.com/questions/18666075/how-to-</a> style-detect-highlighted-boxes-generated-from-browser-native-search-in-pa A developer wants to hide find-in-page results: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://stackoverflow.com/">https://stackoverflow.com/</a> questions/77458310/confuse-browsers-in-built-find-in-page-feature) and could do so by styling them as transparent
*Other signals*:
Ergonomics
None.
Activation
There is no way to polyfill this. There is no real challenge to adopting beyond awareness that the feature exists, and we will be producing blog postings and other social media evangelization.
Security
There is no security risk. The CSS styling is available regardless of whether the text is search for or not, so user find-in-page queries cannot be seen by script.
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
No
Debuggability
There is no security risk. The CSS styling is available regardless of whether the text is search for or not, so user find-in-page queries cannot be seen by script.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes
All platforms support find-in-page and could use CSS styling to improve legibility on some sites.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ? No
Testing is in wpt_internal tests due to a lack of wpt support for adding find-in-page markers. third_party/blink/web_tests/ wpt_internal/css/css-pseudo/search-text-*
DevTrial instructions <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/Igalia/">https://github.com/Igalia/</a> explainers/blob/main/css/find-in-page/README.md
Flag name on about://flags Experimental Web Platform Features
Finch feature name SearchTextHighlightPseudo
Rollout plan Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/339298411">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/339298411</a>
Measurement We will implement UseCounters for this pseudo element (and all the other too, see <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/381093928">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/381093928</a>)
Availability expectation Available in Chrome, and Firefox. Not available in Safari
Adoption expectation Hard to predict and not relevant to most sites
Adoption plan Blog posts and developer outreach
Non-OSS dependencies
Does the feature depend on any code or APIs outside the Chromium open source repository and its open-source dependencies to function? No
Estimated milestones Shipping on desktop 140 DevTrial on desktop 135 Shipping on Android 140 DevTrial on Android 135 Shipping on WebView 140
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). None

entry.title: [blink-dev] Ready for Developer Testing: Probabilistic Reveal Tokens
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Ready for Developer Testing: Probabilistic Reveal Tokens
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Ready+for+Developer+Testing%5C%3A+Probabilistic+Reveal+Tokens%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Ready for Developer Testing: Probabilistic Reveal Tokens</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27Theodore+Olsauskas%5C-Warren%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'Theodore Olsauskas-Warren' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250714" rel="nofollow">Mon, 14 Jul 2025 09:17:00 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails
sau...@google.com, las...@google.com, nick...@google.com, erictrou...@chromium.org, ryanka...@google.com, ayk...@google.com</pre><pre>
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/GoogleChrome/ip-protection/blob/main/prt_explainer.md">https://github.com/GoogleChrome/ip-protection/blob/main/prt_explainer.md</a>
Specification
None
Summary
To ensure that businesses can continue to estimate the amount of fraud on their systems, train models to defend against fraud, and analyze emerging fraudulent behavior while still mitigating the ability to track users at scale using IP addresses, we propose to introduce a delayed IP sampling mechanism called Probabilistic Reveal Tokens (PRTs) alongside IP Protection for use in protected traffic.
PRTs will be included on proxied requests in a new HTTP header added by the browser for domains that indicate they want to receive them via a signup process. Each PRT will contain a ciphertext, generated by an Issuer and re-randomized for unlinkability by the browser prior to the request, that the recipient can decrypt after a delay. Google will be the issuer for Chrome's implementation. A minority of the decrypted PRTs contain the client's pre-proxy IP address (i.e. non-masked, and as observed by the token issuer), while the remaining PRTs provide no information about the client's original IP address. This results in only a small percent of PRTs containing and revealing the user's IP.
Blink component
Privacy>Fingerprinting>IPProtection <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Privacy%3EFingerprinting%3EIPProtection%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Privacy%3EFingerprinting%3EIPProtection%22</a>>
TAG review
None
TAG review status
Pending
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
None
Gecko: No signal
WebKit: No signal
Web developers: No signals
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Goals for experimentation
With this dev trial, developers can configure their local Chrome instance to fetch PRTs from the Google issuer and attach them to all network requests to specific domains. Use of the IP proxy is not required.
Going forward, key publication will proceed as normal. Developers can thus store both issued and sent tokens, for later decryption when keys are published.
In a future state, developers will need to sign up their origins to receive PRTs on proxied requests. No sign-up is necessary to perform the local testing outlined here.
This is intended to allow interested developers to test PRTs and begin considering how they might integrate PRTs into their workflows.
Ongoing technical constraints
None
Debuggability
None
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
No
Supported where IP Protection is supported.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ?
No
DevTrial instructions
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/prtoken-reference/blob/main/prt_dev_testing.md">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/prtoken-reference/blob/main/prt_dev_testing.md</a>
Flag name on about://flags
None
Finch feature name
EnableProbabilisticRevealTokens - Note that there are many subtleties to enabling this feature, please see developer guide.
Requires code in //chrome?
False
Launch bug

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: Script Tools API
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: Script Tools API
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Prototype%5C%3A+Script+Tools+API%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: Script Tools API</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22David+Bokan%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">David Bokan</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250709" rel="nofollow">Wed, 09 Jul 2025 11:06:32 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Thanks! Filled these out in chromestatus - posting inline replies below as well.</pre><pre>
On Wednesday, July 9, 2025 at 1:48:42 PM UTC-4 Reilly Grant wrote:
On Wed, Jul 9, 2025 at 9:36 AM David Bokan <bo...@chromium.org> wrote:
Contact emailsbo...@chromium.org, hvanops...@chromium.org, khushalsagar@ chromium.org
ExplainerNone - We're working to publish an explainer ASAP and will link it on this thread when it's available.
SpecificationNone
Summary
Script Tools enable authors to expose JavaScript APIs on their site for automated use by the user agent. They allow an author to annotate these APIs with descriptions and provide input schema, allowing automation frameworks a more specific method to access the site's functionality.
Blink componentBlink <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%22</a>>
Blink>WebML
Motivation
Automation over web pages is an increasingly active area. Currently, web APIs provide no direct way to interact with automation frameworks so these frameworks rely on simulating user input on pages. Script Tools aims to provide a way for participating web sites to provide automation-specific paths in their UI. Automation can then proceed more quickly and enables the web site's UI to react.
Initial public proposalNone
TAG reviewNone
TAG review statusPending
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
None
Please fill out this section.
Given this is a new space and new API - there's no compatibility risk.
Usual risk related to other browser vendors not adopting the API apply. This API is meant to augment capabilities provided by browser add-ons and so non-adoption in other engines would have limited user-impact and thus we consider the risk to be low.
*Gecko*: No signal
*WebKit*: No signal
*Web developers*: No signals
*Other signals*:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Debuggability
None
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ?No
I assume this will be tested eventually. Are there any blockers to being able to test it with WPT?
That's right, the "No" is to currently but the intent is to eventually test in WPT as much as possible.
Since the API provides the user agent with the ability to call certain tools, we might need to extend the WPT harness to support this. At minimum the IDL and basic usage can and will be tested in WPT.
Flag name on about://flagsNone
Finch feature nameNone
Non-finch justificationNone
Requires code in //chrome?True

No milestones specified

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS find-in-page highlight pseudos
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS find-in-page highlight pseudos
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+CSS+find%5C-in%5C-page+highlight+pseudos%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS find-in-page highlight pseudos</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250709" rel="nofollow">Wed, 09 Jul 2025 12:41:07 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails schen...@chromium.org, ji...@igalia.com </pre><pre>
Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/Igalia/explainers/blob/main/css/find-in-page/README.md">https://github.com/Igalia/explainers/blob/main/css/find-in-page/README.md</a>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-pseudo-4/#selectordef-search-text">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-pseudo-4/#selectordef-search-text</a>
Design docs
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/Igalia/explainers/blob/main/css/find-in-page/README.md">https://github.com/Igalia/explainers/blob/main/css/find-in-page/README.md</a>
Summary
Exposes find-in-page search result styling to authors as a highlight pseudo-element, like selection and spelling errors. This allows authors to change the foreground and background colors or add text decorations, which can be especially useful if the UA defaults have insufficient contrast with the page colors or are otherwise unsuitable.
Blink component Blink>CSS
Search tags search
TAG review None
TAG review status Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
The feature is in the CSS Pseudo spec and there are no open issues. The behavior is designed to be implementable in Firefox and Chrome, but is unlikely to be viable in Safari due to highly customize UI for find-in-page. The spec is explicit that browsers may choose not to implement this feature provided @supports information is correct. The Safari behavior is so different that developers are unlikely to believe their styling would apply there.
Gecko: Under consideration (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1103">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1103</a>)
WebKit: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/421">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/421</a>) Will file a request for position, but in spec conversations were neutral with no expectation of implementing it themselves.
Web developers: Positive Developers wishing to avoid conflicts with the find-in-page colors and their page styles have requested this feature. Someone directly asks for CSS styling of find-in-page:<a rel="nofollow" href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50309703/css-for-browsers-find-in-page">https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50309703/css-for-browsers-find-in-page</a> Another direct question: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/18666075/how-to-style-detect-highlighted-boxes-generated-from-browser-native-search-in-pa">https://stackoverflow.com/questions/18666075/how-to-style-detect-highlighted-boxes-generated-from-browser-native-search-in-pa</a> A developer wants to hide find-in-page results: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/77458310/confuse-browsers-in-built-find-in-page-feature">https://stackoverflow.com/questions/77458310/confuse-browsers-in-built-find-in-page-feature</a>) and could do so by styling them as transparent
Other signals:
Ergonomics
None.
Activation
There is no way to polyfill this. There is no real challenge to adopting beyond awareness that the feature exists, and we will be producing blog postings and other social media evangelization.
Security
There is no security risk. The CSS styling is available regardless of whether the text is search for or not, so user find-in-page queries cannot be seen by script.
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
No
Debuggability
There is no security risk. The CSS styling is available regardless of whether the text is search for or not, so user find-in-page queries cannot be seen by script.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes All platforms support find-in-page and could use CSS styling to improve legibility on some sites.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? No Testing is in wpt_internal tests due to a lack of wpt support for adding find-in-page markers. third_party/blink/web_tests/wpt_internal/css/css-pseudo/search-text-*
DevTrial instructions <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/Igalia/explainers/blob/main/css/find-in-page/README.md">https://github.com/Igalia/explainers/blob/main/css/find-in-page/README.md</a>
Flag name on about://flags Experimental Web Platform Features
Finch feature name SearchTextHighlightPseudo
Rollout plan Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/339298411">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/339298411</a>
Measurement We will implement UseCounters for this pseudo element (and all the other too, see <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/381093928">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/381093928</a>)
Availability expectation Available in Chrome, and Firefox. Not available in Safari
Adoption expectation Hard to predict and not relevant to most sites
Adoption plan Blog posts and developer outreach
Non-OSS dependencies
Does the feature depend on any code or APIs outside the Chromium open source repository and its open-source dependencies to function? No
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop 140
DevTrial on desktop 135
Shipping on Android 140
DevTrial on Android 135
Shipping on WebView 140
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (eg links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (eg, changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). None

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: CSS counter() and counters() in alt text of 'content' property
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: CSS counter() and counters() in alt text of 'content' property
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+CSS+counter%5C%28%5C%29+and+counters%5C%28%5C%29+in+alt+text+of+%27content%27+property%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: CSS counter() and counters() in alt text of 'content' property</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250702" rel="nofollow">Wed, 02 Jul 2025 08:44:55 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM3 (per Yoav's description)
/Daniel</pre><pre>
On 2025-07-02 17:40, Yoav Weiss (@Shopify) wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM2 conditional on two things: 1) Removing the "at risk" label from the spec </pre><tt>2) Including an example in the spec and relevant documentation about </tt><tt>*how* developers are supposed to use this. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>Specifically for (2), since the presence of `counter()` breaks the </tt><tt>"content:" property (as it's invalid syntax in non-supporting </tt><tt>browsers), we want developers that are using this to also provide a </tt><tt>`content:` property that doesn't include a `counter()` and precedes </tt><tt>the one that does. </tt><tt>This needs to be *very* clear to developers that are reaching out for </tt><tt>this tool. </tt><tt>(and right now it isn't. Jeffrey Yasskin on the API owners call </tt><tt>mentioned this is a correct fallback for developers to use) </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On Wednesday, July 2, 2025 at 5:09:07 PM UTC+2 Chris Harrelson wrote:
LGTM1
On Wed, Jun 25, 2025 at 12:46 AM Daniil Sakhapov <sakha...@chromium.org> wrote:
For Blink there are no performance issues as counter value calculation is performed at the same time as for other counters, so it's not really any different from just using counter().
As the real use case for this feature appeared only with Carousel primitives introduction, I don't know of any signals from web devs, but a11y people support it and it's per OpenUI recommendations for Carousels.

<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Secure+Payment+Confirmation%5C%3A+Browser+Bound+Keys%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Secure Payment Confirmation: Browser Bound Keys</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250625" rel="nofollow">Wed, 25 Jun 2025 12:54:32 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<tt>I am curious about this as a vector for privacy intrusion. There is </tt><tt>probably something I have missed so feel free to explain what I am missing. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>These browser bound keys are per design locked to a specific device. </tt><tt>Doesn't that mean that it allows a bad actor to keep track of a user's </tt><tt>devices, or even keep track of users, like some kind of very special </tt><tt>cookie? The explainer talks about this being used in an </tt><tt>embedded/cross-origin environment which means that avoiding tracking is </tt><tt>even more important. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre></pre><tt>How about clearing the data, will this be deleted if a deletes "cookies" </tt><tt>or "browsing data"? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>The explainer says that a full privacy analysis should be done, but that </tt><tt>is from last spring so maybe it has been done? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
/Daniel
On 2025-06-25 17:03, Vladimir Levin wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> That makes sense, thank you for the answers.
LGTM2
On Wednesday, June 25, 2025 at 9:42:19 AM UTC-4 Slobodan Pejic wrote:
Hi Vladimir,
Thanks for the questions:
1. How *do* you avoid replay attacks in this case? If a device is uniquely identified by a key that is only challenged by 2FA (like SMS) on the first try, what prevents a person-in-the-middle from learning this key and using it later?
The clientDataJSON
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/webauthn-2/#dom-authenticatorresponse-clientdatajson">https://www.w3.org/TR/webauthn-2/#dom-authenticatorresponse-clientdatajson</a>> contains a challenge <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/webauthn-2/#dom-collectedclientdata-challenge">https://www.w3.org/TR/webauthn-2/#dom-collectedclientdata-challenge</a>> field: WebAuthn passes clientDataJSON (or rather a hash of the clientDataJSON) to the authenticator for signing. The browser bound key also signs the clientDataJSON containing the challenge. On another transaction a person-in-the-middle does not have access to the browser bound private key needed to sign over the challenge. The relying party can protect against replay attacks by providing a random challenge, checking the challenge matches, and verifying the signature.
2. There is some discussion to switching to a device bound key if WebAuthn supports that. Is the possibility of shared devices considered an acceptable risk? Specifically, SMS 2FA is "your phone number" which can be reasonably thought as your and yours alone, but a device like a desktop is commonly shared device (e.g. library computer). Or is the device key something that changes based on login or some other criteria?
Browser bound keys are associated to the tuple (a passkey, a browser instance, a device) in the Chrome profile, so a separate os login would produce a different browser bound key for the same passkey, and different browser bound keys would be provided for different passkeys in the same profile. If someone is at a library computer, they first need access to the passkey before the matching browser bound key. Secure Payment Confirmation requires userVerification
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://w3c.github.io/webauthn/#dom-publickeycredentialrequestoptions-userverification">https://w3c.github.io/webauthn/#dom-publickeycredentialrequestoptions-userverification</a>> (see SPC spec
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://w3c.github.io/secure-payment-confirmation/#sctn-steps-to-respond-to-a-payment-request">https://w3c.github.io/secure-payment-confirmation/#sctn-steps-to-respond-to-a-payment-request</a>>) when invoking WebAuthn (e.g., on Android enter the lock screen pin/fingerprint, on MacOS provide your fingerprint), so the user must be present to use an existing passkey before the browser bound key would be used to sign the transaction. A different passkey would yield a different browser bound key; however, even if an attacker managed to use a browser bound key on the same library computer with an attacker controlled passkey, then relying parties can detect the mismatch (on top of not recognizing the attacker's passkey).
To be clear, if WebAuthn introduces a form of device-binding, Chrome will continue to provide browser bound keys (i.e., there is no code or spec to switch browser bound key provider to WebAuthn). When or if WebAuthn supports device binding we would re-evaluate the need/requirements for browser bound keys in the web payments working group.
On Tue, Jun 24, 2025 at 9:55 PM Vladimir Levin <vmp...@chromium.org> wrote:
On Tuesday, June 10, 2025 at 2:47:10 PM UTC-4 Chromestatus wrote:
Contact emails slobo...@chromium.org, smcgr...@chromium.org, rous...@chromium.org
Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/271">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/271</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/271">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/271</a>>
In the explainer you mention the following: > It is worth noting that this proposal is in some ways re-inventing the wheel of what already exists and/or will exist in WebAuthn. In particular, it means that we have to be careful to avoid all the traps/problems with signatures that WebAuthn already has solved (e.g., challenges to avoid replay attacks, choice of signing algorithms, quantum-proofing, etc). Where possible, we should look to write the spec relying on WebAuthn concepts, even if the actual key creation and storage does not use WebAuthn authenticators.
I don't follow WebAuthn progress closely, so the questions I have may be naive, but bear with with me.
1. How *do* you avoid replay attacks in this case? If a device is uniquely identified by a key that is only challenged by 2FA (like SMS) on the first try, what prevents a person-in-the-middle from learning this key and using it later?
2. There is some discussion to switching to a device bound key if WebAuthn supports that. Is the possibility of shared devices considered an acceptable risk? Specifically, SMS 2FA is "your phone number" which can be reasonably thought as your and yours alone, but a device like a desktop is commonly shared device (e.g. library computer). Or is the device key something that changes based on login or some other criteria?
Thanks! Vlad

There's a </tt><tt>lot of specification details discussion mixed in as well, but people </tt><tt>can find the design discussion too. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#byob-reader-read">https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#byob-reader-read</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#byob-reader-read">https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#byob-reader-read</a>>
Summary
This feature introduces a min option to the existing ReadableStreamBYOBReader.read(view) API. The API already accepts a ArrayBufferView into which data is read, but currently does not guarantee how many elements will be written before the read resolves. The min option is an additive, opt-in enhancement - it does not affect existing behavior for applications that don’t use it. By specifying a min value, developers can require that the stream wait until at least that many elements are available before resolving the read. This improves upon the current behavior, where reads may resolve with fewer elements than the view can hold.
